chapter.title: Time-Related Services
chapter.para: Keeping system clocks synchronized within a network is required for many databases and authentication services. The following topics are covered in this chapter.

sect1.title: Clock Synchronization (Overview)
sect1.para: The Network Time Protocol (NTP) public domain software from the University of Delaware is included in the Solaris software from Solaris 2.6 release forward. The xntpd daemon sets and maintains the system time-of-day. The xntpd daemon is a complete implementation of the version 3 standard, as defined by RFC 1305.
The xntpd daemon reads the /etc/inet/ntp.conf file at system startup. See xntpd1M for information about configuration options.

itemizedlist.para: Remember the following when using NTP in your network:

listitem.para: The xntpd daemon uses minimal system resources.
An NTP client synchronizes automatically with an NTP server when it boots. If the client becomes unsynchronized, the client resynchronizes again when the client contacts a time server.

sect1.para: Another way to synchronize clocks is to run rdate while using cron.

sect1.title: Managing Network Time Protocol (Tasks)
sect1.para: The following procedures show how to set up and use the NTP service.

task.title: How to Set Up an NTP Server
task.procedure:
&rolestepA;
Create the ntp.conf file.
To ensure proper execution of the xntpd daemon, the ntp.conf file must first be created. The ntp.server file can be used as a template.# cd /etc/inet # cp ntp.server ntp.conf
Start the xntpd daemon.# svcadm enable network/ntp

task.title: How to Set Up an NTP Client
task.procedure:
&rolestepA;
Create the ntp.conf file.
To activate the xntpd daemon, the ntp.conf file must first be created.# cd /etc/inet # cp ntp.client ntp.conf
Start the xntpd daemon.# svcadm enable network/ntp

sect1.title: Using Other Time-Related Commands (Tasks)
sect1.para: The following procedure can be used to update the current time when ever needed, without having to setup NTP.

task.title: How to Synchronize Date and Time From Another System
task.procedure:
&rolestepA;
Reset the date and time to synchronize with another system, by using the rdate command. # rdate another-systemanother-system
Name of the another system
Verify that you have reset your system's date correctly by using the date command.
The output should show a date and time that matches that of the other system.

example.title: Synchronizing Date and Time From Another System
example.para: The following example shows how to use rdate to synchronize the date and time of one system with another. In this example, the system earth, running several hours behind, is reset to match the date and time of the server starbug.
example.screen: earth# date Tue Jun 5 11:08:27 MDT 2001 earth# rdate starbug Tue Jun 5 14:06:37 2001 earth# date Tue Jun 5 14:06:40 MDT 2001
